segments.text: The first televised face-off between Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump will get underway in less than four hours from now.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: It's expected to be the most watched presidential debate in history and could even rival ratings seen during the Super Bowl.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Their first historic face-off is almost here.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton and her Republican rival Donald Trump are gearing up for their first debate on Monday night at one of this century's most anticipated TV events.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Moderated by NBC News anchor Lester Holt, it′s a 90-minute session starting at 9 PM at New York′s Hofstra University.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Clinton and Trump are expected to cover topics including foreign policy and national security issues.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Clinton has three decades of experience in politics and a long history of high-profile debates.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Last Wednesday, she put a pause on campaigning to prepare for the debate.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And Donald Trump, who vanquished nearly a dozen opponents in the Republican debates, has also been getting ready while on the campaign trail.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: It's reported that he's been studying Clinton's past debates to find flaws in her stances on national issues, with the help of Steve Bannon, the CEO of the Trump campaign and others on his team.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Just six weeks ahead of Election Day, the polls show the two candidates neck and neck.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: A poll released on Sunday by ABC News and The Washington Post showed voters are split, with 46 percent for Clinton and 44 percent for Trump, well within the poll's four-and-a-half percentage point margin of error.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Described as debate of the century, Monday night's showdown is expected to draw more than 100 million viewers in the states alone.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And with the rest of the world eyeing this crucial point in the U.S.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: election, it'll be streamed live online through platforms like YouTube.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
